@JCforTeachers @NCCAie 'Engage early teachers and school principles' Early teachers? Those in before 8.20? Those that were born before their due date. And then engage abstract concepts? The sentence doesn't mean anything.

@ronandusty They are awful. Thank god that fad died a death.

@ronandusty I found it more haunting, changing the frame speed seemed to turn them into living ghosts.
Colourising this footage isn't the same as colourising fiction.

Colourising the footage, and having actors 'perform' the words and writings of those alive at the time, is akin to a historian redescribing events as they discuss them, literally a colour commentary. Something is lost but something is also gained.
Fair question but the black and white footage is still there to be watched, analysed and empathised with. https://t.co/ebZfnwBlSx

@johdal That's pretty much what it is. And considering the book had been adapted before I'm not sure how much the narrative elements alone qualify it as a Noir. (I have only seen this one though, so maybe the previous version played around with the story)
@celticman10 All day long!

Small final point. I was never convinced that The Maltese Falcon was really a Film Noir. I'm increasingly convinced that it is just the best adaptation of a popular detective story. (Noir implies a certain style that Maltese Falcon doesn't possess).

Your discussion of Neff and Lola made me think of the Coen brothers' 'Cain' film, The Man Who Wasn't There. When I showed Double Indemnity recently the was a chat about what the hell the two of them were up to.

I was thinking about 1 of the points made about whether we like the two main characters or not. I feel we are entertained by Fred MacMurray. As you pointed out, he was known as light comedic actor not one who'd play an amoral murderer. He plays with this appeal in his performance
Was listening to this when I was doing my various chores today. Possibly the best one yet. https://t.co/F4VQrrT6P3

@johdal I love the book but just not a fan of any of the adaptations. No idea why. (I'm not one of those 'it's not as good as the book' people. See them as sepereate entities)
